thread.title: Map: Search areas for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 - @nytimesworld
thread.title_full: Map: Search areas for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 - @nytimesworld

author: Stephanie Clary
title: Map: Search areas for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 - @nytimesworld
text:
Asia Pacific The Search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 The flight disappeared in the early hours of March 8, 2014, en route to Beijing from Kuala Lumpur with 239 people on board. UPDATED July 30, 2015 Where Debris Could Have Come From Published July 30, 2015 A computer model developed by Erik van Sebille, an oceanographer at the University of New South Wales, uses historical ocean currents data to predict the probable paths that objects could take drifting through the ocean over the course of several months. This map shows the model's predictions for an object washing up on the island of Réunion. Sources: Erik van Sebille, adrift.org.au India detection points Orange circles show where van Sebille's model predicts an object could have originated if it washed up on Réunion after drifting on ocean currents for a year and four months. Larger circles are more likely areas of origin. Kuala Réunion MADAGASCAR According to the model, there is roughly a 10 percent chance that an object that drifted to Réunion originated within the search area for the missing plane. Southern Currents 1,000 MILES Orange circles show where van Sebille's model predicts an object could have originated if it washed up on Réunion after drifting on ocean currents for a year and four months. Larger circles are more likely areas of origin. Malaysia Réunion CURRENTS According to the model, there is roughly a 10 percent chance that an object that drifted to Réunion originated within the search area for the missing plane. Orange circles show where van Sebille's model predicts an object could have originated if it washed up on Réunion after drifting on ocean currents for a year and four months. Larger circles are more likely areas of origin. Radar Southern Currents According to the model, there is roughly a 10 percent chance that an object that drifted to Réunion originated within the search area for the missing plane. 1,000 MILES Sources: Erik van Sebille, adrift.org.au Debris Found on Réunion Published July 29, 2015 A piece of debris, possibly from Flight 370, was found on a French island, Réunion, on Wednesday. Several countries have searched for the missing plane for more than a year in an area off the coast of Australia. The debris was found across the Indian Ocean, more than 2,500 miles from the search areas. Related Article » Sources: Malaysian Transport Ministry, Joint Agency Coordination Centre India Possible flight paths, according to a Malaysian government report Réunion appeared to be an airplane part was found on the shores of this French island. Search Possible debris of an airplane was found on the shores of this French island. Possible appeared to be an airplane part was found on the shores of this French island. Possible flight paths, according to a Malaysian government report Search Sources: Malaysian Transport Ministry, Joint Agency Coordination Centre Possible Flight Paths Published May 2, 2014 The Malaysian government released a report describing the confusion and miscommunication in the hours following the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370. The report included a map showing several possible flight paths for the missing Malaysia Airlines jet. Their analysis of satellite data produced zones of probability showing where the jet could have crashed. Related Article » Source: Malaysian Transport Ministry Underwater Search Updated April 21, 2014 The autonomous underwater vehicle continued its search on Monday. It has completed surveying approximately two-thirds of the focused underwater search area without detecting anything of interest. Related Article » Source: Joint Agency Coordination Centre 200 MILES Source: Joint Agency Coordination Centre One Day’s Worth of Mapping, to Scale Published April 14, 2014 On April 14, officials said an autonomous underwater vehicle will be deployed to map the ocean floor in the area where four "pings" that could be from the plane's flight recorders were detected by an Australian vessel. Each of the vehicle’s missions will take one day to complete and will cover an area of about 15 square miles of seabed. Related Article » Source: Joint Agency Coordination Centre Approximate size of last week’s sonobuoy search area Relative positions of pinger locator detections New York City shown for scale. Autonomous underwater vehicle New York City shown for scale. 5 MILES Approximate size of last week’s sonobuoy search area Relative positions of pinger locator detections Source: Joint Agency Coordination Centre The Lay of the Land, Under the Sea Published April 11, 2014 The Zenith Plateau, formed about 130 million years ago when India and Australia broke apart, lies thousands of feet below the area where an Australian ship detected signals that could be from the plane’s flight recorders. Like most of the ocean, the plateau is poorly mapped. However, the Wallaby Plateau, just to the southeast, has been thoroughly mapped as part of Australia's exclusive economic zone, and, according to David T. Sandwell of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography, "one could assume their sea floor properties will be similar." So, Dr. Sandwell said, the two plateaus are probably soft and smooth, making it easier to spot irregular debris in scan data. Related Article » Sources: David T. Sandwell, Scripps Institution of Oceanography; Walter H.F. Smith, NOAA Laboratory for Satellite Altimetry; deepreef.org Wharton Modern sonar equipment map these six- to 12-mile-wide swaths of the sea floor at a high resolution. 
Older sonar data, collected decades ago, still provides important depth information. 
Basin 100 MILES Bathymetry is the measurement of the ocean floor's depth. The data is currently acquired in two ways: by ships carrying echo sounders (sonar) and by a satellite orbiting the earth that measures ocean surface height variations induced by the gravitational effects of ocean floor topography at a very low resolution. Just 10 to 15 percent of the earth's oceans — and less than 5 percent of the Indian Ocean — have been mapped by echo sounders. The rest of the depth is inferred from the satellite technique. Wharton AUSTRALIA 200 MILES Modern sonar equipment map these 6-12 mile-wide swaths of the sea floor at a high resolution. Older sonar data, collected decades ago, still provides important depth information. Bathymetry is the measurement of the ocean floor's depth. The data is currently acquired in two ways: by ships carrying echo sounders (sonar) and by a satellite orbiting the earth that measures ocean surface height variations induced by the gravitational effects of ocean floor topography at a very low resolution. Just 10 to 15 percent of the earth's oceans — and less than 5 percent of the Indian Ocean — have been mapped by echo sounders. The rest of the depth is inferred from the satellite technique. Sources: David T. Sandwell, Scripps Institution of Oceanography; Walter H.F. Smith, NOAA Laboratory for Satellite Altimetry; deepreef.org Signal Detected By Aircraft Unrelated to Black Box Updated April 11, 2014 Australian authorities said April 11 that the potential signal from a sonobuoy — a sensor dropped into the sea by a Royal Australian Air Force plane — was probably not from the flight recorders, despite hopes raised the previous day. The latest potential clue to the whereabouts of the aircraft came in the same seas off Western Australia where the Ocean Shield, an Australian ship, had already collected four sets of signals — two on April 6 and two on April 8 — that could have come from beacons attached to the plane’s two flight recorders. The average depth in that area is about 15,000 feet. Related Article » Source: Australian Maritime Safety Authority INDIAN OCEAN
